43.  Class members must be adequately represented by Class Counsel and 
12
afforded due process in order to be bound by a class settlement or judgment. Thus, 
13
in class actions, personal jurisdiction for judgment purposes may be exercised over 
14
nonresident class members, even those without minimum contacts with the forum, 
15
and without affirmative opt-in consent having been made, so long as there has 
16
been the best notice practicable under the circumstances, and an opportunity for 
17
class members to exclude themselves from the litigation. Phillips Petroleum Co. v. 
18
Shutts, 472 U.S. 797, 808 (1985). The Court finds that such due process 
19
requirements have been met here, and that it accordingly may bind even those 
20
individuals who are individual plaintiffs who are now absent if they have not 
21
opted out. Accordingly, the Court concludes that Class Counsel’s proposal is 
22
proper. 
23
44.  This is especially so because, without the Court approving the 
24
settlement for the Missing Represented Individuals, the Missing Represented 
25
Individuals, if they are named parties, would be subject to a motion for dismissal 
26
with prejudice for failure to prosecute their case, under F.R.Civ.P. Rule 41(b). See, 
27
e.g., Henderson v. Duncan, 779 F.2d 1421, 1423 (9th Cir.1986) (in ruling on a 
28 motion under Rule 41(b), the Court considers several factors, including, “(1) the 
  14 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 18 of 24
   
1 public's interest in expeditious resolution of litigation; (2) the court's need to 
2 manage its docket; (3) the risk of prejudice to the defendants; (4) the public policy 
3 favoring disposition of cases on their merits and (5) the availability of less drastic 
4 sanctions”); Aziz v. Wright, 34 F.3d 587 (8th Cir. 1994) (plaintiff twice appeared 
5 for deposition but refused each time to be deposed; case properly dismissed for 
failure to prosecute after court ordered plaintiff to be deposed and he failed to 
6
comply). If they were not named parties, they would be bound by the settlement 
7
even though they were receiving no funds. 
8
45.  The Court finds that it is in the interest of the Missing Represented 
9
Individuals, and of the class as a whole, to include the Missing Represented 
10
Individuals in the settlement on the terms proposed, and that it has the authority to 
11
do so in the context of this class action without the approval of the Missing 
12
Represented Individuals. Accordingly, Class Counsel shall open special interest 
13
bearing trust accounts for each such client. If any Missing Represented Individual 
14
has not claimed his/her funds by December 31, 2012, then the funds in the account 
15
for such individual shall revert to the City. Counsel for any Missing Represented 
16
Individual who opens a trust account pursuant to this paragraph shall, at the time 
17
the trust account is opened, provide the financial institution holding the funds 
18
written notice of the City’s reversionary right and all instructions necessary to 
19
facilitate such reversion on January 2, 2013. Counsel for any Missing Represented 
20
Individual shall also give the City written notice, addressed to Cory Brente of the 
21
Los Angeles City Attorney’s Police Litigations Section, of the financial 
22
institution(s) in which any such account has been opened so that the City may take 
23
steps to exercise its reversionary rights at the appropriate time.  It shall then be the 
24
responsibility of the City to initiate the reversionary process and contact any 
25
holders of the trust accounts necessary to accomplish the reversion, with which 
26
process all Plaintiffs’ counsel shall cooperate. Despite the provisions of this 
27
paragraph or any other paragraph herein, between January 1, 2013, and December 
28 31, 2018, each Missing Represented Individual shall retain the right to receive 
  15 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 19 of 24
   
1 from the City (and no other person) the amount of net principal and accrued 
2 interest, if any, that was in the trust account at the time the City received funds 
3 from it; provided, however, that said Missing Individual shall not be entitled to 
4 receive interest accrued after December 31, 2012, if any. The names, settlement 
5 amounts, and counsel for the Missing Represented Individuals are provided in 
Exhibit 4. 
6
46.  The Missing Represented Individuals will be bound by this Consent 
7
Judgment in the same manner as any other class member who has not opted out. 
8
XIII. CLASS FUND ATTORNEYS’ FEES 
9
47.  Plaintiffs have filed a Motion for Attorneys’ Fees requesting payment 
10
of $3,753,000 in attorneys’ fees including litigation costs and medical liens and 
11
costs. The Court approves this request and is entering a separate order addressing 
12
it. 
13
48.  The Court is also advised that, pursuant to contract terms between 
14
attorney and client, some of the non-MIWON attorneys – but not the MIWON 
15
counsel – may receive a percentage of the client’s recovery, as negotiated between 
16
attorney and client. Since these agreements are in the non-MIWON cases, they do 
17
not require court approval. 
18
XIV. CLASS ADMINISTRATOR 
19
49.  The Court reaffirms the appointment of Gilardi & Co., LLC as 
20
Administrator. The Court authorizes the payment, to be made immediately from 
21
the Litt, Estuar, et al. Client Trust Account, of $30,617.80 to cover the 
22
Administrator’s expenses to date. The Class Administrator estimates an additional 
23
$11,315 or possibly more to complete the claims administration (excluding 
24
particular efforts that may be requested by the City at its expense), for which the 
25
Court authorizes payment upon completion. When and if the class distribution 
26
goes forward (i.e., if there is no appeal or there is an appeal and the settlement is 
27
approved at the appellate level or abandoned), then Gilardi & Co. LLC will 
28 receive an additional $200,000 to distribute to class members as part of the class 
  16 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 20 of 24
   
1 fund. 
2 50.  The Administrator shall preserve all written communications from 
3 class members at least until December 31, 2012, or pursuant to further order of the 
4 Court. All written communications received by the Administrator from class 
5 members relating to the settlement shall be available at all reasonable times for 
inspection and copying by counsel for the parties. 
6
51.  In addition to the Administrator, work to distribute the Class Notices 
7
was performed by the Plaintiff Organizations, each of which has filed a 
8
declaration attesting to their outreach efforts. The Court authorizes payment of up 
9
to $20,000, at $40 per hour, for these efforts by Plaintiff Organizations.   
10
52.  Based on the foregoing figures, the Court is aware that the cost of 
11
administration will exceed the original estimate of $50,000. MIWON counsel has 
12
advised the Court that they have succeeded in reducing some of the liens for their 
13
clients, and that they estimate that the total savings will be somewhere between 
14
$50,000 and $100,000. These lien funds are part of the total $3,753,000 requested 
15
by MIWON counsel. MIWON counsel have further advised the Court that, under 
16
their arrangements with their clients, each client is to receive a specified amount, 
17
and counsel assumed responsibility for the liens. Since the amount to be paid to 
18
MIWON counsel is less than their lodestar, the Court approves that any sums 
19
saved by the reduction of liens shall be deemed fees to the MIWON counsel, 
20
except that from that reduction, MIWON counsel shall pay the additional class 
21
administrative costs so that the funds available for distribution to Unrepresented 
22
Class Members remains $200,000.   
23
XV.  GENERAL PROVISIONS 
24
53.  All class members except those who timely filed opt-out forms shall 
25
be bound by this Consent Judgment. 
26
54.  Except as otherwise provided in this Consent Judgment, each party 
27
shall bear its own costs, expenses and attorneys’ fees. 
28 55.  The use of the masculine gender herein is construed to include the 
  17 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 21 of 24
   
1 feminine and/or the neuter where applicable. The use of the singular herein is to be 
2 construed to include the plural where applicable. The use of the plural herein shall 
3 be construed to include the singular where applicable.  
4 56.  The Court reserves and maintains jurisdiction over this settlement, this 
5 Consent Judgment and its provisions, and over the claims administration and 
distribution of the funds. Disagreements between or among parties over aspects of 
6
this Consent Judgment as it relates to monetary relief shall be subject to mediation 
7
before United States Magistrate Judge Carla Woehrle, the mediator who has 
8
mediated this case to date. If mediation is not successful, the matter shall be 
9
brought to this Court for resolution. 
10
57.  At the conclusion of the distribution of the Post Administration Class 
11
Fund, the Administrator shall submit a report to the Court summarizing the 
12
payments made to the Unrepresented Class Members.  
13
XVI. FINAL RESOLUTION  
14
58.  The monetary relief provided for in this Consent Judgment shall 
15
compensate for all alleged violations of rights and all claims by the Damages 
16
Class Members on Matters Alleged in the Lawsuit under any theory of liability 
17
related to the events of May 1, 2007, that come within the Damages Class 
18
definition, except as to monetary damages for those class members who opt out.  
19
59.  The Court hereby dismisses the lawsuit on the merits, with prejudice, 
20
and without further costs, with such dismissal subject only to compliance by the 
21
parties with the terms and conditions of the Settlement Agreement, the Structural 
22
Relief Order, and this Consent Judgment. 
23
60.  With the exception of Antonio Lopez, all Damages Class Members 
24
and Structural Relief Class Members, including all the Represented Individuals 
25
and the Unrepresented Class Members, as well as any and all of their agents, 
26
attorneys and assigns, are hereby severally and permanently barred and enjoined, 
27
to the fullest extent permitted by law, from filing, commencing, instituting, 
28 maintaining, prosecuting or participating in a lawsuit or any other proceeding 
  18 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 22 of 24
   
1 against any of the Defendants or other Released Person, involving or in any way 
2 arising from any of the Matters Alleged in the Lawsuit, including specifically 
3 claims of any class member whose claims are dismissed by this Consent 
4 Judgment.  
5 61.  The Represented Individuals and Unrepresented Class Members 
waive all rights or benefits which they now have or in the future may have under 
6
the terms of California Civil Code §1542, arising from, alleged in, or pertaining to 
7
the Matters Alleged in the Lawsuit, specifically claims related to the events of 
8
May 1, 2007, that come within the Damages Class Member definition, except as to 
9
monetary damages for those class members who have opted out. Section 1542 
10
reads: 
11
“A general release does not extend to claims which the creditor does not 
12
know or suspect to exist in his or her favor at the time of executing the 
13
release, which if known by him or her must have materially affected his or 
14
her settlement with the debtor.” 
15
62.  The Defendants, and all of their agents, attorneys and assigns, waive 
16
and release any and all claims or rights to pursue, initiate, prosecute, or commence 
17
any action or proceeding before any court, administrative agency or other tribunal, 
18
or to file any complaint regarding acts or omissions, by the Plaintiffs in any of the 
19
cases covered in the settlement herein, by any Represented Individuals as defined 
20
herein, and by any Unrepresented Class Members, with respect to any Matters 
21
Alleged in the Lawsuit, including waiver of the right to file a malicious 
22
prosecution action; and further, as it relates to this waiver, expressly waive the 
23
provisions of California Civil Code §1542 recited in the previous paragraph.  
24
63.  Plaintiffs have not relied upon the advice of Class Counsel as to the 
25
legal and/or tax consequences of this settlement, the payment of any money by the 
26
Defendants or the distribution of any settlement funds.  
27
64.  Neither this Consent Judgment, the Settlement Agreement, nor any of 
28 its terms or the negotiations or papers related thereto shall constitute evidence or 
  19 
 
 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 107      Filed 06/23/2009     Page 23 of 24
   
1 an admission by any Defendant or other Released Person that any acts of 
2 wrongdoing have been committed, and they shall not be deemed to create any 
3 inference that there is any liability therefore. Neither this Consent Judgment, nor 
4 the Settlement Agreement, nor any of its terms or the negotiations or papers 
5 related thereto shall be offered or received in evidence or used for any purpose 
whatsoever, in this or any other matter or proceeding in any court, administrative 
6
agency, arbitration, or other tribunal, except insofar as the parties seeks to enforce 
7
the terms of this Consent Judgment or the underlying Settlement Agreement. 
8
65.  Pursuant to Rule 54(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, the 
9
Court finds that there is no just reason for delay and therefore directs entry of this 
10
Consent Judgment. Inasmuch as this disposes of all claims asserted in the lawsuit, 
11
the Court further directs the Clerk to enter an order of dismissal, with prejudice, 
12
pursuant to F.R.Civ.P Rule 41(a)(1)(2). 
13
 
14
   
15
DATED: __________________     
16
A. HOWARD MATZ

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 2 of 7
Ca  2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 2 of 7 
1  The parties to the above-captioned action have submitted this joint Order for 
2  the Court's review and approval, addressing the injunctive relief class certified by 
3  the Court in its Order issued on January 8, 2008.  The court has considered the 
4  joint submission and now issues the following Order: 
5  1.  Basic Principles: 
6  All persons have the right to march, demonstrate, protest, rally or perform 
7  other activities protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution 
8  and the California Constitution.  The government may impose reasonable and 
9  narrowly tailored restrictions on the time, place, and manner of conducting these 
10  activities.  However, any limitations or restrictions placed on demonstrations or 
11  other First Amendment activities must be justified by the requirements of 
12  maintaining public safety, public health, or safe access/egress from the area, and 
should restrict no more speech than necessary to further these substantial 
13 
government interests.  Officers must not be affected by the content of the opinions 
14 
being expressed nor by the race, gender, linguistics, national origin, sexual 
15 
orientation, physical disabilities, appearances, or affiliation of anyone exercising 
16 
lawful rights. 
17 
2.  Helicopters: 
18 
Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) helicopters assigned to monitor 
19 
permitted crowd control incidents shall operate the aircraft at reasonable altitudes 
20 
so as to avoid disruption of First Amendment protected activities.  The Incident 
21 
Commander will coordinate with event organizers to help avoid over flights during 
22 
keynote speaker presentations.  This action is not intended to prevent LAPD 
23 
24  helicopters from response to emergency situations requiring immediate police 
25  presence during such crowd control events. 
26 
27 
28 
2 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 3 of 7
Ca  2:07 -cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 3 of 7 
1  3.  Marches: 
2  Demonstrators, while participating in lawful assemblages, shall not be 
3  prevented from using public sidewalks to join or exit a lawful march or from using 
4  any public sidewalk adjacent to a lawful march route.  However, while on the 
5  sidewalk, marchers will not be allowed to obstruct or unreasonably interfere with 
6  pedestrian movement and/or prevent lawfully open businesses from operating 
7  when such conduct violates any applicable law.  LAPD will consider the 
8  practicality of facilitating demonstrations that may temporarily block traffic and 
9  LAPD shall include the subject in its Crowd Management training. 
10  4.  Motorcycles/Bicycles/Motor Vehicles: 
11  Police motorcycles, bicycles, and motor vehicles may be used for the 
12  purpose of observation, visible deterrence, traffic control, transportation and area 
control during a crowd event.  When used at the back of a march, they should 
13 
maintain a reasonably safe distance behind the marchers.  LAPD personnel will not 
14 
utilize motorcycles, bicycles, or motor vehicles to strike assembled 
15 
demonstrators/marchers as a method for crowd control or crowd dispersal. 
16 
5.  Crowd Management Training - Horses: 
17 
In its crowd management training, the LAPD shall include a subject on the 
18 
impact of the use of horses on crowd behavior. 
19 
6.  Use of Less Lethal Weapons: 
20 
Less-lethal munitions are categorized as projectiles launched or otherwise 
21 
deployed for the purpose of overcoming resistance, effecting arrest or addressing 
22 
the threat of serious injury to an officer or suspect with less risk of causing death 
23 
than the use of a firearm. 
24 
a.  Less-lethal munitions may be deployed on aggressive and/or 
25 
combative suspects in a crowd control situation, on suspects who 
26 
27 
28 
3 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 4 of 7
Ca  2:07 -cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 4 of 7 
1  are a potential physical threat to themselves or others, or suspects 
2  displaying "aggressive" and/or "combative" actions. 
3  b.  For the purpose of deployment ofless-Iethal munitions, 
4  "aggressive" and/or "combative" actions include ongoing 
5  destruction of property that presents a threat to the personal safety 
6  of officers or others. 
7  c.  Less lethal weapons should not be used on a lawfully dispersing 
8  crowd or individual. 
9  d.  Less lethal weapons should not be used against a person or a crowd 
10  that is retreating unless the person or crowd continues to engage in 
11  unlawful activity that is aggressive and/or combative. 
12  e.  Where feasible, notice should be given to the crowd before less 
lethal weapons are deployed in a crowd control or dispersal 
13 
situation, and where feasible, it should be given in the language(s) 
14 
spoken by those assembled. 
15 
f.  If the LAPD resumes the use of stinger rounds, the LAPD will 
16 
publish a notice that will require that less-lethal stinger weapons 
17 
can be used only with the approval of a staff officer (i.e., 
18 
commander or above) and only in a riotous situation where the use 
19 
of lethal force would not be reasonable. 
20 
7.  Use of Batons: 
21 
Batons should not be used against members of the crowd attempting to 
22 
disperse, persons unable to move because of the press of the crowd, or persons 
23 
otherwise posing no imminent threat to the officers or other persons.  Batons may 
24 
be displayed or used in a pushing motion when used as a justified and authorized 
25 
crowd management technique.  The baton may be used to push individuals who 
26 
intentionally delay dispersal subsequent to a lawful order to disperse.  When an 
27 
28 
4 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 5 of 7
Ca  2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 5 of 7 
1  individual's behavior is threatening or violent in nature, the baton may be used as 
2  an impact device in accordance with Department policy. 
3  8.  Public Assemblies: 
4  The Incident Commander and supervisors shall make every effort to ensure 
5  that the police mission is accomplished as efficiently as possible, with the highest 
6  regard for human dignity and liberty of all persons, with consideration of the 
7  cultural and linguistic diversity of the neighborhoods and communities of Los 
8  Angeles, and with minimum reliance on the use of physical force.  Incident 
9  Commanders, prior to declaring an assembly unlawful, will follow the procedures 
as directed in the LAPD Guidelines for Crowd Management and Crowd Control, 
10 
11  Volume 5 of the LAPD Emergency Operations Guide.  Before any public assembly 
is declared to be unlawful, the Incident Commander should evaluate the feasibility 
12 
of isolating and arresting those responsible for the unlawful conduct, and if it is 
13 
determined to be feasible, shall take such action. 
14 
9.  Declaration of Unlawful Assembly: 
15 
Crowd dispersal techniques shall not be initiated until after a declaration has 
16 
been announced as required by California Penal Code Section 409.  LAPD 
17 
personnel will follow the procedures as directed in the LAPD Guidelines for 
18 
Crowd Management and Crowd Control, Volume 5 of the LAPD Emergency 
19 
Operations Guide.  The following factors shall be considered when issuing a 
20 
dispersal order: 
21 
a.  Use of an amplified loudspeaker system to issue the order. 
22 
b. If feasible, send an officer to the far side of the crowd to tape record 
23 
the order. 
24 
c.  If circumstances permit (absence of serious violence), the order 
25 
shall be made repeatedly over a period of time and, if necessary, 
26 
from a variety of locations. 
27 
28 
5 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 6 of 7
Ca  2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 6 of 7 
1  d.  The order must include an objectively reasonable period of time to 
2  disperse and a clear and safe route to disperse based on the facts 
3  and circumstances known at the time. 
4  e.  An order to disperse shall be given in a manner reasonably 
5  calculated to be heard by the entire crowd under the circumstances. 
6  When it is known that members of the crowd do not understand 
7  English, an effort should be made, when feasible, to give the order 
8  to disperse in both English and the other language(s). 
9  f.  The order to disperse shall include a warning that police action may 
10  include the use of less lethal munitions, which could cause 
11  significant risk of serious injury to those who remain. 
12  10.  Crowd Management Training - Shows of Force 
13  In its crowd management training, the LAPD shall include a subject on the 
14  impact of shows of force on crowd behavior. 
15  11.  LAPD's Policy Regarding Crowd Control: 
LAPD's policy regarding crowd control can be found in the Emergency 
16 
Operations Guide, Volume 5, Chapter 7.  All LAPD directives and orders directly 
17 
related to crowd control and the relevant portions of this agreement shall be 
18 
included in the Emergency Operations Guide by July 1,2009.  The plaintiffs shall 
19 
20  be given an opportunity to provide input and comment on the revisions prior to 
21  final approval by the LAPD. 
12.  Training on Crowd Control Policies: 
22 
The LAPD shall require Metropolitan Division to undergo training annually, 
23 
and every officer at the level of Sergeant I and above to undergo training at 
24 
25  minimum intervals of two years, on the Crowd Control and Use of Force policies 
26  to be developed pursuant to Paragraph 11 of this document.  The Department's 
27  existing training, designed and implemented after May 1,2007, will be reviewed 
28 
6 

Case 2:07-cv-03072-AHM-FFM     Document 112      Filed 06/24/2009     Page 7 of 7
Ca  2:07 -cv-03072-AHM-FFM  Document 109  Filed 06/23/2009  Page 7 of 7 
1  and modified, as necessary, to conform to the policies developed as part of this 
2  agreement.  The training may be live or bye-module, or both, at the Department's 
3  discretion. 
4  13.  Retention of Jurisdiction: 
5  The Court retains jurisdiction to enforce the terms of this judgment and to 
6  issue all orders necessary to do so.  The Court's jurisdiction shall continue for a 
7  period of four years and may be extended-in whole or in part-for an additional 
8  period of two years upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence that the 
9  activities complained of are due to the Department's failure to substantially comply 
10  with the provisions of this order. 
11  Before bringing a motion to enforce this order, plaintiffs shall give 
12  defendants notice of an alleged violation and a reasonable opportunity to remedy it. 
13  If necessary to permit defendants adequate time to remedy the alleged failure to 
14  comply, the parties will submit a joint request to extend the Court's initial period 
15  of jurisdiction. 
T JUDGE
